s1: Real-time and embedded systems are all around us. Controlling cars, trains, or aeroplanes, as well as mobile phones, cameras, or A/V equipment, embedded systems are a challenging and demanding part of computer science and engineering.
s2: Critically assess and compare philosophical views on issues arising from elementary logic.

s1: This course delivers foundations of real-time analysis and implementation of systems which are interconnected with the physical world (embedded systems).
s2: Explain the relationship between rules of deduction and the semantics of logic.

s1: It also delivers the principles of fault tolerant systems and highly reliable systems.
s2: Critically assess and compare philosophical views on issues arising from elementary logic.

s1: Techniques which are introduced include real-time calculus, real-time scheduling, elementary sensor data filtering and fusion methods, error recovery strategies, and graceful degradation methods.
s2: Techniques of formal deduction and tests for the validity of arguments will be studied.
